title: Inequalities and Absolute Values
content:
Module 2, Lesson 7: Inequalities and Absolute Values

Introduction

Inequalities compare two expressions using <, >, ≤, or ≥. They define ranges of values rather than single solutions and are essential for modelling constraints in optimisation, engineering tolerances, and probability bounds. Absolute value inequalities extend this to two-sided constraints on distance from a point.

Key Concepts

1. Properties of Inequalities

Adding/subtracting the same quantity preserves the inequality. Multiplying/dividing by a positive number preserves it; by a negative number reverses it. Transitivity: a < b and b < c implies a < c.

2. Compound Inequalities

Conjunction (AND): a < x < b — x lies between a and b. Disjunction (OR): x < a or x > b. Represent on number line and write as interval notation: [a, b], (a, b), (–∞, a) ∪ (b, ∞).

3. Absolute Value Equations

|x| = k (k ≥ 0) gives x = k or x = –k. |2x – 3| = 7 → 2x – 3 = 7 (x = 5) or 2x – 3 = –7 (x = –2).

4. Absolute Value Inequalities

|x| < k ↔ –k < x < k (intersection). |x| > k ↔ x < –k or x > k (union). These represent proximity to or distance from a point on the number line.

Summary

Inequalities model ranges and constraints. You solved compound inequalities, absolute value equations and inequalities, and used interval notation. These concepts are central to analysis, optimisation, and real-world constraint modelling.
